front.title: JSContact: Converting from and to vCard

abstract.t: This document defines how to convert contact information defined in the JSContact specification from and to vCard.

section.name: Motivation
section.t: The JSContact data model and format aims to be an alternative to the widely used vCard standard and jCard .

While applications might prefer JSContact to exchange contact card data with other systems, they are likely to interoperate with services and clients that only support vCard or jCard. Similarly, existing contact data providers and consumers already using vCard or jCard might want to represent their contact data also in JSContact.
To achieve this, this document defines a standard how to convert contact data between JSContact and vCard (and consequently jCard).

section.name: Scope and Caveats
section.t: JSContact and vCard have a lot of semantics in common, however some differences must be outlined:

li.t: The JSContact data model defines some contact information that doesn't have a direct conversion with vCard properties. In particular, unlike vCard, JSContact distinguishes between a single contact card, named Card, and a group of contact cards, named CardGroup.

ul.li: The properties that can be present multiple times in a vCard are represented through different collections in JSContact; mainly as maps, sometimes as arrays, in some cases condensed in a single value.

section.name: Conventions Used in This Document
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .
In the following of this document, the vCard features, namely properties and parameters, are written in uppercase while the Card/CardGroup features are written in camel case wrapped in double quotes.

section.name: Converting vCard to JSContact
section.t: This section contains the conversion rules from vCard to JSContact Card/CardGroup. Its follows the same structure as the vCard v4 RFC document. Properties and parameters of vCard extension RFCs, including the vCard JSContact Extension RFC are added to appropriate subsections.

section.name: Card or CardGroup
section.t: The vCard format represents a contact and a group of contacts both as a vCard object. In contrast, JSContact defines two distinct object types: Card for a contact representing a single entity, CardGroup for a group of contacts. The following rules define which JSContact object type to choose:

ul.li: If the vCard does not contain the KIND property, or the value of this property is anything but group then convert it to a Card object.

If the KIND property value is group then choose a CardGroup object. If the vCard contains any standard properties that do not convert to a standard CardGroup property, convert the vCard also to a Card and use that as the value of the card property in the CardGroup.

section.name: The uid property
section.t: The UID property in vCard is optional, but the uid property in JSContact is mandatory. Implementations that convert a vCard without UID property MUST generate a unique identifier as value for the uid property. They SHOULD generate the same identifier when repeatedly converting the same vCard, but they MAY generate different values. Consequently, a vCard without UID property MAY does not convert to one exact instance of a JSContact card or card group.

section.name: Choosing identifiers
section.t: Multi-valued properties in JSContact typically are represented as a JSON object where the object keys are of the Id type and the object values are the converted vCard property. In absence of the PROP-ID parameter (see ), implementations are free to choose any identifier for such entries. Whatever identifier generation scheme implementations use, they SHOULD generate values of short character length. For example, this could be an incrementing number across all Ids or only unique within one JSON object.

section.name: TEXT
section.t: This converts to the JSContact String type.

section.name: URI
section.t: This converts to the JSContact String type.

section.name: DATE, TIME, DATE-TIME, DATE-AND-OR-TIME, and TIMESTAMP
section.t: The TIMESTAMP type generally converts to the UTCDateTime. It converts to the Timestamp type for anniversaries.
The DATE type converts to the PartialDate type, which only is relevant for anniversaries. This does not apply to DATE values that only define a month or a day.

The TIME, DATE-TIME, DATE-AND-OR-TIME types and DATE type values that only define a month or day do not convert to any JSContact type. vCard properties or parameters having such values MAY convert as defined in .

section.name: BOOLEAN
section.t: This converts to the JSContact Boolean type.

section.name: INTEGER
section.t: This converts to the JSContact Number type.

section.name: FLOAT
section.t: This converts to the JSContact Int and UnsignedInt types.

section.name: UTC-OFFSET
section.t: This either converts to a String containing an IANA TimeZone Database entry name (see ), or it does not convert to any JSContact type. For the latter, vCard properties or parameters having such values MAY convert to JSContact as defined in .

section.name: LANGUAGE-TAG
section.t: This converts to the JSContact String type.

section.name: LANGUAGE
section.t: This converts to an entry in the localizations property for the vCard property that this parameter is set on. The value of the LANGUAGE parameter defines the language key in the localizations property. The JSON pointer in the PatchObject is the path to the JSContact property that the vCard property converts to. The value of the PatchObject is the converted property value.
Note that an entry in the localizations MAY but need not point to an existing property. The following two examples illustrate each case.

figure.name: LANGUAGE conversion example: patch existing property
LANGUAGE conversion example: patch new property

section.name: VALUE
section.t: This does not convert to a standard property in JSContact. It is implicit for standard types and conversion. For extended values, see .

section.name: PREF
section.t: This converts to the pref property defined in

section.name: ALTID
section.t: This does not convert to a standard property in JSContact. To convert this parameter, see .

section.name: PID
section.t: This does not convert to a standard property in JSContact. To convert this parameter, see .

section.name: TYPE
section.t: This converts to the contexts property defined in as well as property-specific type property values defined in later sections.

section.name: MEDIATYPE
section.t: This converts to the mediaType property of the Resource object type.

section.name: CALSCALE
section.t: This parameter set on a BDAY or ANNIVERSARY property converts to the calendarScale property of the PartialDate object type. To convert this parameter for other vCard properties, see .

section.name: SORT-AS
section.t: This does not convert to a standard property in JSContact. To convert this parameter, see .

section.name: GEO
section.t: This parameter set on a ADR property converts to the JSContact coordinates property of the Address object that represents the vCard ADR. To convert this parameter for other vCard properties, see .

section.name: TZ
section.t: This parameter set on a ADR property converts to the JSContact timeZone property of the Address object that represents the vCard ADR. Also see the conversion of the TZ property in . To convert this parameter for other vCard properties, see .

section.name: DERIVED
section.t: If this parameter is set to true on a vCard property, then implementations MAY choose to not convert that property. Note: This parameter is defined in .

section.name: PROP-ID
section.t: The PROP-ID parameter value of a vCard property converts to the Id of the JSContact property to which the vCard property converts to.

figure.name: PROP-ID conversion example

section.t: Note: This parameter is defined in .

section.name: BEGIN and END
section.t: These do not convert to standard properties in JSContact.

section.name: SOURCE
section.t: A SOURCE property converts to an entry in the directories property (). The entry value is a DirectoryResource object whose type property is set to entry and uri property is set to the SOURCE value.
The PREF and MEDIATYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

section.name: KIND
section.t: The KIND property converts to the kind property (). Allowed values are those described in Section 6.1.4 of and extended with the values declared in and . The value group is reserved for a CardGroup instance.

section.name: XML
section.t: This does not convert to a standard property in JSContact.

section.name: FN
section.t: All the FN instances are represented through the fullName property (). The presence of multiple instances is implicitly associated with the full name translation in various languages regardless of the presence of the ALTID parameter. Each translation converts according to the rules as defined in .
If the vCard represents a group of contacts, implementers MAY convert the FN property into either "CardGroup.card.fullName" or "CardGroup.name" or both properties.

section.name: N and NICKNAME
section.t: The N instances convert to equivalent items of the components array of the name property (): the N components convert into related NameComponent objects as presented in . Name componentsSHOULDbe ordered such that their values joined by whitespace produce a valid full name of this entity.
A NICKNAME property converts to an entry in the nickNames property (). The entry value is a NickName object. The name property is set to the NICKNAME value.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

figure.name: FN, N, NICKNAME conversion example

section.name: PHOTO
section.t: A PHOTO property converts to an entry in the media property (). The entry value is a MediaResource object whose type property is set to photo and uri property is set to the PHOTO value.
The PREF and MEDIATYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

section.name: BDAY, BIRTHPLACE, DEATHDATE, DEATHPLACE, ANNIVERSARY
section.t: The BDAY and ANNIVERSARY properties and the extensions BIRTHPLACE, DEATHDATE, DEATHPLACE described in are represented as Anniversary objects included in the anniversaries property ():

li.t: BDAY and BIRTHPLACE convert to date and place where type is set to "birth";
DEATHDATE and DEATHPLACE convert to date and place where type is set to "death";

ul.li: ANNIVERSARY converts to date where type is empty and label is set to a value describing in detail the kind of anniversary (e.g. "marriage date" for the wedding anniversary).

section.t: Both birth and death places are represented as instances of the Address object.

The BIRTHPLACE and DEATHPLACE properties that are represented as geo URIs convert to Address instances including only the coordinates property. If the URI value is not a geo URI, the place is ignored.
The ALTID and LANGUAGE parameters of both BIRTHPLACE and DEATHPLACE properties convert according to the rules as defined in .

figure.name: BDAY, BIRTHPLACE, DEATHDATE, DEATHPLACE, ANNIVERSARY conversion example

section.name: GENDER
section.t: This does not map to a standard property in JSContact. To convert this property, see . Note the alternative JSContact speakToAs property which defines how to address and refer to an individual represented by the card, as do the newly defined vCard GRAMMATICAL-GENDER and PRONOUNS properties of .

section.name: GRAMMATICAL-GENDER and PRONOUNS
section.t: The GRAMMATICAL-GENDER property converts to the grammaticalGender property of the SpeakToAs object ().
The PRONOUNS property converts to an entry in the pronouns property of the SpeakToAs object ().

figure.name: GRAMMATICAL-GENDER and PRONOUNS conversion example

section.name: ADR
section.t: An ADR property converts to an entry in the addresses property (). The entry value is an Address object.
The ADR components convert into the Address properties as presented in and .
The "street address" and "extended address" ADR components MAY be converted into either a single StreetComponent item or a combination of StreetComponent items.

table.name: ADR components vs. Address members conversion
ADR components vs. StreetComponent items conversion

section.t: The LABEL parameter converts to the fullAddress property.
The GEO parameter converts to the coordinates property.
The TZ parameter converts to the timeZone property.
The CC parameter as defined in converts to the countryCode property.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

The ALTID and LANGUAGE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in . Each possible language-dependent alternative is represented as an entry of the PatchObject map where the key references the fullAddress property.

figure.name: ADR conversion example
figure.artwork:
BEGIN:VCARD VERSION:4.0 ... ADR;TYPE=work;CC=US:;;54321 Oak St;Reston;VA;20190;USA ADR;TYPE=home;CC=US:;;12345 Elm St;Reston;VA;20190;USA ... END:VCARD
{ "@type": "Card", ... "addresses": { "ADDR-1" : { "@type": "Address", "contexts": { "work": true }, "fullAddress": "54321 Oak St
Reston
VA
20190
USA", "street": [ { "@type": "StreetComponent", "type": "name", "value": "Oak St" }, { "@type": "StreetComponent", "type": "number", "value": "54321" } ], "locality": "Reston", "region": "VA", "country": "USA", "postcode": "20190", "countryCode": "US" }, "ADDR-2": { "@type": "Address", "contexts": { "private": true }, "fullAddress": "12345 Elm St
Reston
VA
20190
USA", "street": [ { "@type": "StreetComponent", "type": "name", "value": "Elm St" }, { "@type": "StreetComponent", "type": "number", "value": "12345" } ], "locality": "Reston", "region": "VA", "country": "USA", "postcode": "20190", "countryCode": "US" } }, ... }

section.name: TEL
section.t: A TEL property converts to an entry in the phones property (). The entry value is a Phone object. The TEL-specific values of the TYPE parameter convert to the features property keys. The phone property is set to the TEL value.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

figure.name: TEL conversion example

section.name: EMAIL
section.t: An EMAIL property converts to an entry in the emails property (). The entry value is an EmailAddress object. The email property is set to the EMAIL value.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

figure.name: EMAIL conversion example

section.name: IMPP
section.t: An IMPP property converts to an entry in the onlineServices property (). The entry value is a OnlineService object and the uri property is set to the IMPP value.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

section.name: LANG
section.t: A LANG property converts to an entry in the preferredContactLanguages property (). The entry keys correspond to the language tags, the related entry values are arrays of ContactLanguage objects.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .
If both PREF and TYPE parameters are missing, the array of ContactLanguage objects MUST be empty.

figure.name: LANG conversion example

section.name: CONTACT-CHANNEL-PREF
section.t: A CONTACT-CHANNEL-PREF property converts to an entry in the preferredContactChannels property (). The entry key set is defined in , the related entry values are arrays of ContactChannelPreference objects.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .
If both PREF and TYPE parameters are missing, the array of ContactChannelPreference objects MUST be empty.
Note: This property is defined in .

section.name: LOCALE
section.t: The LOCALE property converts to the locale property ().
Note: This property is defined in .

section.name: TZ
section.t: A value of type TEXT converts to the timeZone property in the Address object.
A value of type UTC-OFFSET converts to the timeZone property in the Address object if the offset has zero minutes and the hour offset is in the range -12 <= 14:

ul.li: If the hour offset is zero, use the time zone name Etc/UTC.

Otherwise construct the time zone name with ETC/GMT suffixed with the string representation of the reversed sign hour offset, including the sign but excluding leading zeros and minutes. For example, the UTC offset value -0500 converts to ETC/GMT+5.

section.t: For such property values, also see to determine which Address object instance to convert to.
Any other value of type UTC-OFFSET or URI does not convert to a standard property in JSContact. To convert such property, see .

section.name: GEO
section.t: This converts to the coordinates property of the Address object. Also see to determine which Address object instance to convert to.

section.name: Combining geographical properties
section.t: In vCard the properties ADR, GEO and TZ occur independently of each other. In JSContact, they all convert to properties of an Address object. It is implementation-specific if these vCard properties convert to separate address instances in JSContact, or if some or all of them convert to the same address. That being said, implementations SHOULD convert the properties to the same address for the following cases:

ul.li: The ALTID parameter values of the properties match.
The ALTID parameters are not set, but are set on any other ADR, GEO and TZ properties.

section.name: TITLE and ROLE
section.t: Both TITLE and ROLE properties are represented as entries of the titles property (). The entry value is a Title object whose type property is set to "title"/"role" and title property is set to the TITLE/ROLE value. The rules to set the organization property are out of the scope of this document.
The ALTID and LANGUAGE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

figure.name: TITLE and ROLE conversion example

section.name: LOGO
section.t: A LOGO property converts to an entry in the media property (). The entry value is a MediaResource object whose type property is set to logo and uri property is set to the LOGO value.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

section.name: ORG
section.t: An ORG property converts to an entry in the organizations property (). The entry value is an Organization object whose name property contains the organizational name and the units property contains the organizational units.
Implementations MAY allow to represent organizational untits without the organizational name. In this case, the first component of the ORG value MUST be an empty string (e.g. ORG:;DepartmentA).
The ALTID and LANGUAGE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

figure.name: ORG conversion example

section.name: MEMBER
section.t: According to the JSContact specification, a group of contact cards is represented through a CardGroup (). The uids of the contact cards composing the group are included in the members property.
In this case, the PREF parameter has not a JSContact counterpart; however, the implementers MAY insert the map entries by order of preference.

figure.name: Group example
figure.artwork:
BEGIN:VCARD VERSION:4.0 KIND:group FN:The Doe family MEMBER:urn:uuid:03a0e51f-d1aa-4385-8a53-e29025acd8af MEMBER:urn:uuid:b8767877-b4a1-4c70-9acc-505d3819e519 END:VCARD
{ "@type": "CardGroup", "kind": "group", "fullName": "The Doe family", "uid": "urn:uuid:ab4310aa-fa43-11e9-8f0b-362b9e155667", "members": { "urn:uuid:03a0e51f-d1aa-4385-8a53-e29025acd8af": true, "urn:uuid:b8767877-b4a1-4c70-9acc-505d3819e519": true } }

section.t: Only if the GROUP contains properties that don't have a conversion to CardGroup properties, then the CardGroup.card property MAY contain the optional Card object of this group.

figure.name: card member of CardGroup object

section.name: RELATED
section.t: All the RELATED instances convert to the relatedTo property (): an entry for each entity the entity described by the Card is associated with. The map keys are the uid values of the associated cards.
Each map value is a Relation object including only the relation property represented as a set of the RELATED-specific values of the TYPE parameter as defined in Section 6.6.6 of .
If the relation type is unspecified, the relation property MUST be empty.

figure.name: RELATED conversion example

section.name: CONTACT-URI
section.t: A CONTACT-URI property as defined in is represented as an entry of the links property (). The entry value is a LinkResource object whose type property is set to contact and uri property is set to the CONTACT-URI value.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

section.name: Personal Information Properties
section.t: The LEVEL parameter as defined in is directly converted to the level property of the PersonalInformation type apart from when LEVEL is used in the EXPERTISE property; in this case, the values convert as in the following:

ul.li: "beginner" converts to "low";
"average" converts to "medium";
"expert" converts to "high".

section.name: EXPERTISE
section.t: An EXPERTISE property as defined in is represented as a PersonalInformation object in the personalInfo property (). The type property is set to "expertise".
The INDEX parameter is represented as the index of the expertise among the declared expertises.

figure.name: EXPERTISE conversion example
figure.artwork:
BEGIN:VCARD VERSION:4.0 ... EXPERTISE;LEVEL=beginner;INDEX=2:chinese literature EXPERTISE;INDEX=1;LEVEL=expert:chemistry ... END:VCARD
{ "@type": "Card", ... "personalInfo": { ... "PERSINFO-1" : { "@type": "PersonalInformation", "type": "expertise", "value": "chemistry", "level": "high" }, "PERSINFO-2" : { "@type": "PersonalInformation", "type": "expertise", "value": "chinese literature", "level": "low" }, ... }, ... }

section.name: HOBBY
section.t: A HOBBY property as defined in is represented as a PersonalInformation object in the personalInfo property (). The type property is set to "hobby".
The INDEX parameter is represented as the index of the hobby among the declared hobbies.

section.name: INTEREST
section.t: An INTEREST property as defined in is represented as a PersonalInformation object in the personalInfo property (). The type property is set to "interest".
The INDEX parameter is represented as the index of the interest among the declared interests.

figure.name: INTEREST conversion example
figure.artwork:
BEGIN:VCARD VERSION:4.0 ... INTEREST;INDEX=1;LEVEL=medium:r&b music INTEREST;INDEX=2;LEVEL=high:rock ’n’ roll music ... END:VCARD
{ "@type": "Card", ... "personalInfo": { ... "PERSINFO-1" : { "@type": "PersonalInformation", "type": "interest", "value": "r&b music", "level": "medium" }, "PERSINFO-2" : { "@type": "PersonalInformation", "type": "interest", "value": "rock ’n’ roll music", "level": "high" }, ... }, ... }

section.name: ORG-DIRECTORY
section.t: An ORG-DIRECTORY property as defined in is represented as an entry of the directories property (). The entry value is a DirectoryResource object whose type property is set to directory and uri property is set to the ORG-DIRECTORY value.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .
The INDEX parameter is represented as the index of the directory among the online resources with the directory type.

section.name: CATEGORIES
section.t: A CATEGORIES property converts to a set of entries of the keywords property (). The keys are the comma-separated text values of the CATEGORIES property.
In this case, the PREF parameter has not a JSContact counterpart; however, the implementers MAY insert the map entries by order of preference.

figure.name: CATEGORIES conversion example
figure.artwork:
BEGIN:VCARD VERSION:4.0 ... CATEGORIES:INTERNET,IETF,INDUSTRY,INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY ... END:VCARD
{ "@type": "Card", ... "keywords": { "INTERNET": true, "IETF": true, "INDUSTRY": true, "INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY": true }, ... }

section.name: NOTE
section.t: A NOTE property converts to a Note object in the notes array ()
The ALTID and LANGUAGE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

figure.name: NOTE conversion example

section.name: PRODID
section.t: The PRODID property converts to the prodId property ().

figure.name: PRODID conversion example
figure.artwork:
BEGIN:VCARD VERSION:4.0 ... PRODID:-//ONLINE DIRECTORY//NONSGML Version 1//EN ... END:VCARD
{ "@type": "Card", ... "prodId": "-//ONLINE DIRECTORY//NONSGML Version 1//EN", ... }

section.name: REV
section.t: The REV property converts to the updated property ().

section.name: SOUND
section.t: A SOUND property converts to an entry in the media property (). The entry value is a MediaResource object whose type property is set to sound and uri property is set to the SOUND value.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

section.name: UID
section.t: The UID property corresponds to the uid property () in both Card and CardGroup.

section.name: CLIENTPIDMAP and PID Parameter
section.t: The CLIENTPIDMAP property and the PDI parameter don't have a direct match with a Card feature.

section.name: URL
section.t: An URL property converts to an entry in the links property (). The entry value is a LinkResource object whose uri property is set to the URL value.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

section.name: VERSION
section.t: The VERSION property doesn't have a direct match with a JSContact feature.

section.name: CREATED
section.t: The CREATED property converts to the created property ().
Note: This property is defined in .

section.name: KEY
section.t: A KEY property converts to an entry in the cryptoKeys property (). The entry value is a CryptoResource object whose uri property is set to the KEY value.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

section.name: FBURL
section.t: An FBURL property converts to an entry in the calendars property (). The entry value is a CalendarResource object whose type property is set to freeBusy and uri property is set to the FBURL value.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

section.name: CALADRURI
section.t: A CALADRURI property converts to an entry in the scheduling property (). The entry value is a Scheduling object whose sendTo property includes an entry whose key is set to imip and value is set to the CALADRURI value.
The PREF parameter converts according to the rules as defined in .

section.name: CALURI
section.t: A CALURI property converts to an entry in the calendars property (). The entry value is a CalendarResource object whose type property is set to calendar and uri property is set to the CALURI value.
The PREF and TYPE parameters convert according to the rules as defined in .

section.name: Extended Properties and Parameters
section.t: These convert as specified in .

section.name: New JSContact properties
section.t: vCards may contain properties or parameters for which no standard JSContact property is defined. For example, a vCard may contain extended properties and parameters of which the semantics or purpose are unknown .

This section defines JSContact extension properties by which such vCard properties and parameters MAY be represented in JSContact. Implementations MAY choose to convert differently if they deem that more appropriate.

dl.dd: JCardProp[], where JCardProp denotes a jCard-encoded vCard property as defined in .

This property is set on a JSContact object that represents a vCard. It contains properties that are set in the vCard represented by this JSContact object. Each entry in this list typically represents a vCard property for which no conversion to a standard JSContact property is defined. It MAY contain vCard standard properties which also got converted to a standard property in the same JSContact object. In case of conflict, the values of the JSContact property MUST be used.

dd.t: This illustrates how to convert a vCard extension property:

dl.dd: This property is set on a JSContact object that represents a vCard property. Its value MUST be a JSON object containing vCard property parameters, defined as array element 2 in . Each entry represents a parameter of the vCard property that converts to the JSContact object. Typically, these are parameters for which no standard property is defined in the JSContact object. It MAY contain vCard standard parameters which also got converted to a standard property in the same JSContact object. In case of conflict, the values of the JSContact property MUST be used.

section.name: Conversion Rules
section.t: A Card or CardGroup converts to vCard by applying the reserve rules of section . The following additional rules apply:

ul.li: Multi-valued JSContact properties convert to separate instances of the same vCard property, and for each the PROP-ID parameter MUST be set to the Id of the converted value (see ).

The fullName property in JSContact is optional, but it is mandatory in vCard. If the fullName is not set but the name property is, then implementations MAY derive the value of the FN property from it. In this case, they MUST the DERIVED parameter on the FN property. Otherwise they MUST set the FN property with an empty value.
Vendor-extension and unknown properties convert to vCard as outlined in section .

section.name: New vCard Properties and Parameters
section.t: JSContact objects and their embedded object types may contain properties for which no standard vCard property is defined. For example, a JSContact object may contain extended properties of which the semantics or purpose is unknown .

This section defines an vCard extension property and parameter by which such JSContact properties MAY be represented in JSContact. Implementations MAY choose to convert differently if they deem that more appropriate.

dl.dd: This property represents a JSContact property in vCard.
URI, also see Format Definition for value restrictions.
The property can be specified multiple times in a vCard.

The X-RFC0000-JSPATH parameter MUST be set exactly once for this property. The VALUE parameter MAY be set once, in which case its value MUST be URI. Other IANA and non-standard property parameters can be specified on this property.

dd.t: This property converts a JSContact property to iCalendar. The property name is defined using the X-RFC0000-JSPATH parameter (). A JSContact property value is represented as a data URL using the data scheme . The mediatype part of the URL MUST be application/json and MUST NOT define parameters. The data part of the URL contains the value of the JSContact property. The value MAY base64-encoded, in which case the data URL MUST set the base64 part accordingly.
This property is defined by the following notation:
This illustrates how to convert both complex and simple typed JSContact properties.

figure.name: JSON boolean value conversion example
figure.artwork:
{ "@type": "Card", ... "foo": true }
BEGIN:VCARD VERSION:4.0 ... X-RFC0000-JSPROP;X-RFC0000-JSPATH="foo": data:application/json;true ... END:VCARD

dl.dd: This parameter defines the name of a JSContact property that got converted to a vCard property. It is encoded as a PatchObject pointer as defined in

dd.sourcecode: jspath-param = "X-RFC0000-JSPATH" "=" DQUOTE *QSAFE-CHAR DQUOTE ; also see param-value in RFC 6350, section 3.3

dl.dd: This parameter is set on a X-RFC0000-JSPROP or X-RFC0000-PROP property. Its value defines the name of the JSContact property that got converted to this vCard property. The parameter value contains the JSON pointer of the JSContact property. It MUST be quoted to preserve case.

section.name: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document has no actions for IANA.

section.name: Implementation Status
section.t: NOTE: Please remove this section and the reference to RFC 7942 prior to publication as an RFC.

This section records the status of known implementations of the protocol as defined in this specification at the time of posting of this Internet-Draft, and is based on a proposal described in . The description of implementations in this section is intended to assist the IETF in its decision processes in progressing drafts to RFCs. Please note that the listing of any individual implementation here does not imply endorsement by the IETF. Furthermore, no effort has been spent to verify the information presented here that was supplied by IETF contributors. This is not intended as, and must not be construed to be, a catalog of available implementations or their features. Readers are advised to note that other implementations may exist.

According to RFC 7942, "this will allow reviewers and working groups to assign due considerationto documents that have the benefit of running code, which may serve as evidence of valuable experimentation and feedback that have made the implemented protocols more mature. It is up to the individual working groups to use this information as they see fit".

ul.li: Responsible Organization: National Research Council (CNR) of Italy
Location: https://github.com/consiglionazionaledellericerche/jscontact-tools
Description: This implementation includes tools for JSContact creation, validation, serialization/deserialization, and conversion from vCard, xCard and jCard.
Level of Maturity: This is an "alpha" test implementation.
Coverage: This implementation includes all of the features described in this specification.
Contact Information: Mario Loffredo, mario.loffredo@iit.cnr.it

section.name: Security Considerations
section.t: This document doesn't present any security consideration.

section.name: Preserving vCard property groups
section.t: The vCard format allows to define groups of properties in a vCard. To do so, implementation must prefix the content line of a property with a group identifier, as defined in . There is no equivalent in JSContact, and it is up to further discussion in the working group if and how property groups should be defined. This section contains one possible conversion of vCard property groups in order to preserve them during conversion between the two formats.

section.name: propertyGroups Property
section.t: Type: String[PropertyGroup] (optional).

This combines properties of a JSContact object into named groups. A client implementation can then display these properties together, such as group that combines an organization, address and photo property, shown together with a custom group label.

The object keys MUST only contain ASCII alphanumeric characters (A-Za-z0-9) and hyphen (-) and MUST NOT be an empty string. A key identifies a group within a JSContact object but does not have any additional purpose. Specifically, the key is not meant to provide a human-readable name of the group. For this, use the PropertyGroup label property. A PropertyGroup object has the following properties:

ul.li: @type: String (mandatory). Specifies the type of this object. This MUST be PropertyGroup.
label: String (optional). A human-readable label or name of this property group.

members: String[Boolean] (optional). The set of property members of this property group. It MUST contain at least one member to be valid. The keys are the path to a property, encoded as a JSON pointer where the leading / character is implicit (a pointer implicitly starts at the top-level of the Card or CardGroup). Any path that points at or into the propertyGroups property MUST be ignored. The values of the set MUST be true.
